title: About
text:
About Me
Hello! My name is Vibha Dara and I am a rising senior at Neuqua Valley High School in Illinois. I am very passionate about Computer Science and Statistics which is what I hope to be majoring in and working in in the future. My hobbies include swimming, playing badminton, listening to music, and hanging out with friends.

title: About
text:
About This Project
I was able to make this website through the Kane’s Free Data Science Course which teaches the basics of data science and statistics with R!

title: Graphs
text:
Factors 1 & 2





Among individuals with glucose levels below 100 in this sample, diabetic patients have higher insulin levels compared to non-diabetic patients. However, for individuals with glucose levels exceeding 100, diabetic patients show lower insulin levels in comparison to non-diabetic patients, indicating a potential impairment in glucose regulation among individuals with diabetes.

title: Graphs
text:
Factor 3





The higher position of the boxplot for the diabetes group suggests a correlation between diabetes and higher BMI levels as there would be a disruption in glucose metabolism.

title: Graphs
text:
Factor 4





The boxplot for the diabetes group is only slightly higher than that of the non-diabetes group which suggests a weak correlation between diabetes and blood pressure levels. There could be other factors that play a more significant role in influencing blood pressure outcomes.

title: Diabetes Analysis
text:
Introduction
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), diabetes is one of the top 10 leading causes of death in the U.S. and more than 37 million people in the U.S. have diabetes. Below is an image of how diabetes among Americans is growing immensely as the years go on. I’ll first see if diabetes is more prevalent in a particular age or gender and then analyze potential factors that contribute to this disease.

title: Models
text:
Age and Gender





Take-away: It is more common for males to have diabetes than females. As age increases, the likeliness of getting diabetes becomes higher and higher. There is a spike at around 80 years old with almost 14 percent of the sample having the disease.

title: Models
text:
Data Model


stan_glm
 family:       binomial [logit]
 formula:      diabetes ~ age + gender
 observations: 1250
 predictors:   3
------
            Median MAD_SD
(Intercept) -4.70   0.35 
age          0.04   0.01 
genderMale   0.40   0.20 

------
* For help interpreting the printed output see ?print.stanreg
* For info on the priors used see ?prior_summary.stanreg


Analysis: The age and genderMale median being positive shows that males are more likely to have diabetes than females and that the likeliness of diabetes increases with age. However, the median absolute deviation indicates that there is some uncertainty regarding the association between gender, age, and diabetes.
